page.title: 02RIVER STUDY: AFON LWYD
page.content: The river{Afon Lwyd}runs through a valley{(or Cwm)}which was ground out by a{glacier}millions of years ago. It runs, North to South, for about 13 miles. Its source is in the moun- tains above{Abersychan.}From there it flows through{Pontewynydd, Pontypool, {Llanfrechfa}until it reaches{Caerleon, just above{Newport,}where it flows into the{River Usk}(eventually to join the{River Severn}and{Bristol Channel). The name{Afon Lwyd}is Welsh and means{'grey water'.}Although it has been very polluted in the past, the river is now clean and only looks grey because of the{limestone bedrock. Sewage still runs into the river but it is so clean now that it is full of life (e.g. salmon and trout). {A railway}was built alongside it in {1852}and{a canal}was joined to it in {1797.}It has{flooded only once c1930.
